por.por_cntn:
Project Firebirds are STEM Teacher (FAST) Capacity
Building Grant

Final Project Outcomes Report

June 2015


The project, “Firebirds Are STEM Teachers -Capacity” (Project FAST Capacity) at the University of the District of Columbia,  focused
on developing UDC’s capacity in areas essential to a high quality teacher
preparation program for aspiring middle-school science teachers.  Project FAST had as its four outcomes:

• Curriculum:  ready-to-teach curriculum for a MAT concentration in Middle School Science

• Curricular Authority: Program approval for the MAT concentration in Middle School Science

• Curricular Supports: Programmatic support materials in place to ‘wrap around’ the rich, rigorous curriculum

• STEM Network: Strong, engaged network of STEM professionals and partner institutions prepared to support program implementation including faculty and mentors and partners for experiential learning.

Project FASTCapacity’s creation of a teacher preparation program in middle-school science, specifically for preparing aspiring teachers from underrepresented minority backgrounds, has poised the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) to admit its first cohort of aspiring middle science teachers for Academic Year 2016.  Partnerships with DC Public DCPS) (and
Public Charter (DCPCS) middle schools provide fertile ground for the growth and development of teachers who understand the context and opportunities urban schools provide.  Our recruitment efforts are targeting under-represented minorities to be trained in cutting edge approaches tailored towards teaching middle grade students who are diverse in terms of culture, language, and learning styles/abilities.  It is anticipated that by attracting and
training this group of teachers for urban middle school settings they will encourage and inspire students, especially minorities, to select career pathways in STEM fields. Achieving this expectation will contribute to a desired societal outcome of having greater percentages of minorities and especially women in STEM careers. 

The teacher education curriculum developed by Project FAST Capacity has as its main pillars Academic language of Science, Practice of Science and Next Generation Science Standards.  One of our key consultants and development partners, Center for Applied Linguistics (CAL) provided the framework and guidance for preparing curriculum materials for teachers who are astute in framing differentiated lesson activities to meet the needs of diverse urban middle-school learners specifically in understanding academic language of science.  Another of our key partners, Carnegie
Institution of Science’s Center for Academic Science Education (CASE), worked with the project team to create the ready-to-teach curriculum which
strategically includes practice of science and the Next Generation Science Standards.  The curriculum is complete with syllabi,assessments, and teaching/learning resources as well access to a cadre of bench
research scientists secured by CASE who will mentor our teacher candidates in connecting with the practice of science. 

The project team’s close collaboration with our third partners District of Columbia Public Schools (DCPS) and District of Columbia Public Charter (DCPCS) middle schools resulted in a test phase for curricula materials around the academic language of science.  Teachers were also involved
in shaping the syllabi for three methods courses which is part of the curriculum.  With the advice of CASE and collaborating mi...
por.por_txt_cntn:
Project Firebirds are STEM Teacher (FAST) Capacity
Building Grant
Final Project Outcomes Report
June 2015


The project, "Firebirds Are STEM Teachers -Capacity" (Project FAST Capacity) at the University of the District of Columbia,  focused
on developing UDCÆs capacity in areas essential to a high quality teacher
preparation program for aspiring middle-school science teachers.  Project FAST had as its four outcomes:

• Curriculum:  ready-to-teach curriculum for a MAT concentration in Middle School Science

• Curricular Authority: Program approval for the MAT concentration in Middle School Science

• Curricular Supports: Programmatic support materials in place to æwrap aroundÆ the rich, rigorous curriculum

• STEM Network: Strong, engaged network of STEM professionals and partner institutions prepared to support program implementation including faculty and mentors and partners for experiential learning.

Project FASTCapacityÆs creation of a teacher preparation program in middle-school science, specifically for preparing aspiring teachers from underrepresented minority backgrounds, has poised the University of the District of Columbia (UDC) to admit its first cohort of aspiring middle science teachers for Academic Year 2016.  Partnerships with DC Public DCPS) (and
Public Charter (DCPCS) middle schools provide fertile ground for the growth and development of teachers who understand the context and opportunities urban schools provide.  Our recruitment efforts are targeting under-represented minorities to be trained in cutting edge approaches tailored towards teaching middle grade students who are diverse in terms of culture, language, and learning styles/abilities.  It is anticipated that by attracting and
training this group of teachers for urban middle school settings they will encourage and inspire students, especially minorities, to select career pathways in STEM fields. Achieving this expectation will contribute to a desired societal outcome of having greater percentages of minorities and especially women in STEM careers. 

The teacher education curriculum developed by Project FAST Capacity has as its main pillars Academic language of Science, Practice of Science and Next Generation Science Standards.  One of our key consultants and development partners, Center for Applied Linguistics (CAL) provided the framework and guidance for preparing curriculum materials for teachers who are astute in framing differentiated lesson activities to meet the needs of diverse urban middle-school learners specifically in understanding academic language of science.  Another of our key partners, Carnegie
Institution of ScienceÆs Center for Academic Science Education (CASE), worked with the project team to create the ready-to-teach curriculum which
strategically includes practice of science and the Next Generation Science Standards.  The curriculum is complete with syllabi,assessments, and teaching/learning resources as well access to a cadre of bench
research scientists secured by CASE who will mentor our teacher candidates in connecting with the practice of science. 

The project teamÆs close collaboration with our third partners District of Columbia Public Schools (DCPS) and District of Columbia Public Charter (DCPCS) middle schools resulted in a test phase for curricula materials around the academic language of science.  Teachers were also involved
in shaping the syllabi for three methods courses which is part of the curriculum.  With the advice of CASE and collaborating middle schools from DCPS and DCPCS, the project team procured science learning and
teaching resources mostly related to physical, earth and apace science units
for middle grades.
